newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks tumble at close amid rate fears.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks tumble at close amid rate fears.

text.p: Mexican stocks on Tuesday closed sharply down for the fifth session in a row after forecasts of an impending surge in primary interest rates triggered a sell-off in late trade, dealers said.
"It was frightful. The bourse took a battering, discounting the rates hike we'll see this evening," a Mexico City desk trader said.
The leading IPC share index ended down 40.23 points, or 1.06 percent, at 3,755.69. Trading volume picked up in late trade to 114.1 million shares.
"What happened was that the forecast increase in primary rates rose, and the peso sagged in late trade," the trader said.

Later Tuesday, Banco de Mexico is expected to assign bellwether 28-day Cetes at an average of 21.61 percent, up 302 basis points from its auction last week, according to Reuters survey of eight money market traders in Mexico City.
Benchmark 48-hour peso contracts meanwhile were 0.2 of a centavo softer at 7.9930/7.9970.

Traders said Mexican stocks suffered amid a late slide on Wall Street, where investors succumbed to a bout of jitters ahead of congressional testimony on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, the U.S. Federal Reserve chairman.
Still, it was local factors that weighed most heavily on Mexican share prices, they said.
"Dealers aren't too worried over Greenspan or the Dow. Besides, that would have hit ADRs," another desk trader said.
The Dow Jones closed off 0.96 percent at 6,852.72 points.
Telmex ADRs ended up 1/8 at 38-5/8, while media group Telmex gained one dollar to 25.
Meanwhile, Telmex L shares ended six centavos higher at 15.40 pesos, and Televisa CPO shares gained 3.30 pesos to 99.50 pesos.
Technical analysts said the IPC index ended near support, which they situated at 3,750 points.
"The IPC failed to respect intermediate support at 3,770 points, and should it break through at 3,750 points, we could go down to 3,700," said Hctor Jimnez, an analyst at the Inverlat brokerage.
"The problem here is that it fell at heavy volume," he said.
On the broad market, 109 stocks changed hands, of which decliners outnumbered gainers by 62 to 27.
Steelmaker Ahmsa, down 42 centavos to 16.90 pesos, was the most heavily traded decliner, though dealers said that mostly reflected a cross trade of more than 10 million shares.
Another leading decliner was Carso Global Telecom, off 1.40 pesos at 23.00 pesos.
Publishing firm Gfesa, up 18 centavos to 1.70 pesos, topped the gainers' list after announcing a Bankers Trust subsidiary had formalized its acquisition of a minority shareholding in the company.
((--Karina Balderas, Mexico City newsroom +525 728-9562))
